translation_text.mn26:17.1: I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. Traveling stage by stage in the Magadhan lands, I arrived at the town of Senā in Uruvelā.
translation_text.mn26:17.2: There I saw a delightful park, a lovely grove with a flowing river that was clean and charming, with smooth banks. And nearby was a village to resort to for alms.
translation_text.mn26:17.4: ‘This park is truly delightful, a lovely grove with a flowing river that’s clean and charming, with smooth banks. And nearby there’s a village to resort to for alms.
translation_text.mn26:17.5: This is good enough for striving for a gentleman wanting to strive.’
translation_text.mn26:17.6: So I sat down right there, thinking,
translation_text.mn26:18.1: And so, being myself liable to be reborn, understanding the drawbacks in being liable to be reborn, I sought that which is free of rebirth, the supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment—and I found it. Being myself liable to grow old, fall sick, die, sorrow, and become corrupted, understanding the drawbacks in these things, I sought that which is free of old age, sickness, death, sorrow, and corruption, the supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment—and I found it.
translation_text.mn26:18.2: Knowledge and vision arose in me:
translation_text.mn26:18.3: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’
translation_text.mn26:19.2: ‘This principle I have discovered is deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute.
translation_text.mn26:19.3: But people like clinging, they love it and enjoy it.
translation_text.mn26:19.4: It’s hard for them to see this topic; that is, specific conditionality, dependent origination.
translation_text.mn26:19.5: It’s also hard for them to see this topic; that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.
translation_text.mn26:19.6: And if I were to teach this principle, others might not understand me, which would be wearying and troublesome for me.’
translation_text.mn26:19.7: And then these verses, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, occurred to me:
translation_text.mn26:19.9: enough with trying to explain it!
translation_text.mn26:19.10: Those mired in greed and hate
translation_text.mn26:19.12: It goes against the stream, subtle,
translation_text.mn26:19.14: Those besotted by greed cannot see,
translation_text.mn26:19.15: for they’re shrouded in a mass of darkness.’
translation_text.mn26:19.16: So, as I reflected like this, my mind inclined to remaining passive, not to teaching the Dhamma.
translation_text.mn26:20.1: Then the divinity Sahampati, knowing my train of thought, thought,
translation_text.mn26:20.2: ‘Oh lord! The world will be lost, the world will perish! For the mind of the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, inclines to remaining passive, not to teaching the Dhamma.’
translation_text.mn26:20.3: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the realm of divinity and reappeared in front of me.
translation_text.mn26:20.4: He arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward me, and said,
translation_text.mn26:20.5: ‘Sir, let the Blessed One teach the Dhamma! Let the Holy One teach the Dhamma!
translation_text.mn26:20.6: There are beings with little dust in their eyes. They’re in decline because they haven’t heard the teaching.
translation_text.mn26:20.7: There will be those who understand the teaching!’
translation_text.mn26:20.8: That’s what the divinity Sahampati said.
translation_text.mn26:20.9: Then he went on to say:
translation_text.mn26:20.10: ‘Among the Magadhans there appeared in the past
translation_text.mn26:20.11: an impure teaching thought up by the stained.
translation_text.mn26:20.12: Fling open the door to freedom from death!
translation_text.mn26:20.13: Let them hear the teaching <j>the immaculate one discovered.
translation_text.mn26:20.14: Standing high on a rocky mountain,
translation_text.mn26:20.15: you can see the people all around.
translation_text.mn26:20.16: In just the same way, All-seer, so intelligent,
translation_text.mn26:20.17: having ascended the Temple of Truth,
translation_text.mn26:20.18: rid of sorrow, look upon the people
translation_text.mn26:20.19: swamped with sorrow, overcome by rebirth and old age.
translation_text.mn26:20.20: Rise, hero! Victor in battle, caravan leader,
translation_text.mn26:20.21: wander the world cleared of debt.
translation_text.mn26:20.22: Let the Blessed One teach the Dhamma!
translation_text.mn26:20.23: There will be those who understand!’
translation_text.mn26:21.1: Then, understanding the Divinity’s invitation, I surveyed the world with the eye of a Buddha, because of my compassion for sentient beings.
translation_text.mn26:21.2: And I saw sentient beings with little dust in their eyes, and some with much dust in their eyes; with keen faculties and with weak faculties, with good qualities and with bad qualities, easy to teach and hard to teach. And some of them lived seeing the danger in the fault to do with the next world, while others did not.
translation_text.mn26:21.3: It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses. Some of them sprout and grow in the water without rising above it, thriving underwater. Some of them sprout and grow in the water reaching the water’s surface. And some of them sprout and grow in the water but rise up above the water and stand with no water clinging to them.
translation_text.mn26:21.4: In the same way, I saw sentient beings with little dust in their eyes, and some with much dust in their eyes.
translation_text.mn26:21.5: Then I replied in verse to the divinity Sahampati:
translation_text.mn26:21.6: ‘Flung open are the doors to freedom from death!
translation_text.mn26:21.7: Let those with ears to hear commit to faith.
translation_text.mn26:21.8: Thinking it would be troublesome, Divinity, <j>I did not teach
translation_text.mn26:21.9: the sophisticated, sublime Dhamma among mankind.’
translation_text.mn26:21.10: Then the divinity Sahampati, knowing that his request for me to teach the Dhamma had been granted, bowed and respectfully circled me, keeping me on his right, before vanishing right there.
translation_text.mn26:22.2: ‘Who should I teach first of all?
translation_text.mn26:22.3: Who will quickly understand this teaching?’
translation_text.mn26:22.5: ‘That Āḷāra Kālāma is astute, competent, clever, and has long had little dust in his eyes.
translation_text.mn26:22.6: Why don’t I teach him first of all?
translation_text.mn26:22.8: But a deity came to me and said,
translation_text.mn26:22.9: ‘Sir, Āḷāra Kālāma passed away seven days ago.’
translation_text.mn26:22.10: And knowledge and vision arose in me,
translation_text.mn26:22.11: ‘Āḷāra Kālāma passed away seven days ago.’
translation_text.mn26:22.13: ‘This is a great loss for Āḷāra Kālāma.
translation_text.mn26:22.14: If he had heard the teaching, he would have understood it quickly.’
translation_text.mn26:23.2: ‘Who should I teach first of all?
translation_text.mn26:23.3: Who will quickly understand this teaching?’
translation_text.mn26:23.5: ‘That Uddaka son of Rāma is astute, competent, clever, and has long had little dust in his eyes.
translation_text.mn26:23.6: Why don’t I teach him first of all?
translation_text.mn26:23.8: But a deity came to me and said,
translation_text.mn26:23.9: ‘Sir, Uddaka son of Rāma passed away just last night.’
translation_text.mn26:23.10: And knowledge and vision arose in me,
translation_text.mn26:23.11: ‘Uddaka son of Rāma passed away just last night.’
translation_text.mn26:23.13: ‘This is a great loss for Uddaka.
translation_text.mn26:23.14: If he had heard the teaching, he would have understood it quickly.’
translation_text.mn26:24.2: ‘Who should I teach first of all?
translation_text.mn26:24.3: Who will quickly understand this teaching?’
translation_text.mn26:24.5: ‘The group of five mendicants were very helpful to me. They looked after me during my time of resolute striving.
translation_text.mn26:24.6: Why don’t I teach them first of all?’
translation_text.mn26:24.8: ‘Where are the group of five mendicants staying these days?’
translation_text.mn26:24.9: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman I saw that the group of five mendicants were staying near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.
translation_text.mn26:24.10: So, when I had stayed in Uruvelā as long as I pleased, I set out for Varanasi.
translation_text.mn26:25.1: While I was traveling along the road between Gayā and Bodhgaya, the Ājīvaka ascetic Upaka saw me
translation_text.mn26:25.3: ‘Reverend, your faculties are so very clear, and your complexion is pure and bright.
translation_text.mn26:25.4: In whose name have you gone forth, reverend? Who is your Teacher? Whose teaching do you believe in?’
translation_text.mn26:25.5: I replied to Upaka in verse:
translation_text.mn26:25.6: ‘I am the champion, the knower of all,
translation_text.mn26:25.7: unsullied in the midst of all things.
translation_text.mn26:25.8: I’ve given up all, freed through the ending of craving.
translation_text.mn26:25.9: Since I know for myself, whose follower should I be?
translation_text.mn26:25.12: In the world with its gods,
translation_text.mn26:25.14: For in this world, I am the perfected one;
translation_text.mn26:25.18: I am going to the city of Kāsi
translation_text.mn26:25.19: to roll forth the Wheel of Dhamma.
translation_text.mn26:25.20: In this world that is so blind,
translation_text.mn26:25.21: I’ll beat the drum of freedom from death!’
translation_text.mn26:25.22: ‘According to what you claim, reverend, you ought to be the Infinite Victor.’
translation_text.mn26:25.23: ‘The victors are those who, like me,
translation_text.mn26:25.24: have reached the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn26:25.25: I have conquered bad qualities, Upaka—
translation_text.mn26:25.27: When I had spoken, Upaka said: ‘If you say so, reverend.’ Shaking his head, he took a wrong turn and left.
translation_text.mn26:26.1: Traveling stage by stage, I arrived at Varanasi, and went to see the group of five mendicants in the deer park at Isipatana.
translation_text.mn26:26.2: The group of five mendicants saw me coming off in the distance
translation_text.mn26:26.4: ‘Here comes the ascetic Gotama. He’s so indulgent; he strayed from the struggle and returned to indulgence.
translation_text.mn26:26.5: We shouldn’t bow to him or rise for him or receive his bowl and robe.
translation_text.mn26:26.6: But we can set out a seat; he can sit if he likes.’
translation_text.mn26:26.7: Yet as I drew closer, the group of five mendicants were unable to stop themselves per their own agreement.
translation_text.mn26:26.8: Some came out to greet me and receive my bowl and robe, some spread out a seat, while others set out water for washing my feet.
translation_text.mn26:26.9: But they still addressed me by name and as ‘reverend’.
translation_text.mn26:27.2: ‘Mendicants, don’t address me by name and as “reverend”.
translation_text.mn26:27.3: The Realized One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn26:27.4: Listen up, mendicants: I have achieved freedom from death! I shall instruct you, I will teach you the Dhamma.
translation_text.mn26:27.5: By practicing as instructed you will soon realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. You will live having achieved with your own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’
translation_text.mn26:27.7: ‘Reverend Gotama, even by that conduct, that practice, that grueling work you did not achieve any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones. How could you have achieved such a state now that you’ve become indulgent, strayed from the struggle and returned to indulgence?’
translation_text.mn26:27.9: ‘The Realized One has not become indulgent, strayed from the struggle and returned to indulgence.
translation_text.mn26:27.10: The Realized One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn26:27.11: Listen up, mendicants: I have achieved freedom from death! I shall instruct you, I will teach you the Dhamma.
translation_text.mn26:27.12: By practicing as instructed you will soon realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life.’
translation_text.mn26:27.13: But for a second time they said to me,
translation_text.mn26:27.15: So for a second time I said to them,
translation_text.mn26:27.16: ‘The Realized One has not become indulgent …’
translation_text.mn26:27.18: But for a third time they said to me,
translation_text.mn26:27.19: ‘Reverend Gotama, even by that conduct, that practice, that grueling work you did not achieve any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones. How could you have achieved such a state now that you’ve become indulgent, strayed from the struggle and returned to indulgence?’
translation_text.mn26:28.2: ‘Mendicants, have you ever known me to speak like this before?’
translation_text.mn26:28.4: ‘The Realized One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn26:28.5: Listen up, mendicants: I have achieved freedom from death! I shall instruct you, I will teach you the Dhamma.
translation_text.mn26:28.6: By practicing as instructed you will soon realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. You will live having achieved with your own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’
translation_text.mn26:29.1: I was able to persuade the group of five mendicants.
translation_text.mn26:29.2: Then sometimes I advised two mendicants, while the other three went for alms.
translation_text.mn26:29.3: Then those three would feed all six of us with what they brought back.
translation_text.mn26:29.4: Sometimes I advised three mendicants, while the other two went for alms.
translation_text.mn26:29.5: Then those two would feed all six of us with what they brought back.
translation_text.mn26:30.1: As the group of five mendicants were being advised and instructed by me like this, being themselves liable to be reborn, understanding the drawbacks in being liable to be reborn, they sought that which is free of rebirth, the supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment—and they found it. Being themselves liable to grow old, fall sick, die, sorrow, and become corrupted, understanding the drawbacks in these things, they sought that which is free of old age, sickness, death, sorrow, and corruption, the supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment—and they found it.
translation_text.mn26:30.2: Knowledge and vision arose in them:
translation_text.mn26:30.3: ‘Our freedom is unshakable; this is our last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’
translation_text.mn26:31.1: Mendicants, there are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn26:31.3: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn26:31.7: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn26:31.8: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn26:32.1: There are ascetics and brahmins who enjoy these five kinds of sensual stimulation tied, infatuated, attached, blind to the drawbacks, and not understanding the escape. You should understand that they
translation_text.mn26:32.2: have met with calamity and disaster, and the Wicked One can do with them what he wants.
translation_text.mn26:32.3: Suppose a deer in the wilderness was lying caught on a pile of snares.
translation_text.mn26:32.5: has met with calamity and disaster, and the hunter can do with them what he wants.
translation_text.mn26:32.6: And when the hunter comes, it cannot flee where it wants.
translation_text.mn26:32.7: In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who enjoy these five kinds of sensual stimulation tied, infatuated, attached, blind to the drawbacks, and not understanding the escape. You should understand that they
translation_text.mn26:32.8: have met with calamity and disaster, and the Wicked One can do with them what he wants.
translation_text.mn26:33.1: There are ascetics and brahmins who enjoy these five kinds of sensual stimulation without being tied, infatuated, or attached, seeing the drawbacks, and understanding the escape. You should understand that they
translation_text.mn26:33.2: haven’t met with calamity and disaster, and the Wicked One cannot do what he wants with them.
translation_text.mn26:33.3: Suppose a deer in the wilderness was lying on a pile of snares without being caught.
translation_text.mn26:33.5: hasn’t met with calamity and disaster, and the hunter cannot do what he wants with them.
translation_text.mn26:33.6: And when the hunter comes, it can flee where it wants.
translation_text.mn26:33.7: In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who enjoy these five kinds of sensual stimulation without being tied, infatuated, or attached, seeing the drawbacks, and understanding the escape. You should understand that they
translation_text.mn26:33.8: haven’t met with calamity and disaster, and the Wicked One cannot do what he wants with them.
translation_text.mn26:34.1: Suppose there was a wild deer wandering in the forest that walked, stood, sat, and laid down in confidence.
translation_text.mn26:34.3: Because it’s out of the hunter’s range.
translation_text.mn26:34.4: In the same way, a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn26:34.5: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra, put out his eyes without a trace, and gone where the Wicked One cannot see.
translation_text.mn26:35.1: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn26:35.2: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
translation_text.mn26:36.1: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
translation_text.mn26:36.2: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
translation_text.mn26:37.1: Furthermore, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.mn26:37.2: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
translation_text.mn26:38.1: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.
translation_text.mn26:38.2: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
translation_text.mn26:39.1: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
translation_text.mn26:39.2: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
translation_text.mn26:40.1: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.
translation_text.mn26:40.2: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
translation_text.mn26:41.1: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
translation_text.mn26:41.2: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
translation_text.mn26:42.1: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.
translation_text.mn26:42.2: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra, put out his eyes without a trace, and gone where the Wicked One cannot see.
translation_text.mn26:42.3: They’ve crossed over clinging to the world. And they walk, stand, sit, and lie down in confidence.
translation_text.mn26:42.5: Because they’re out of the Wicked One’s range.”
translation_text.mn26:42.6: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn26:42.7: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
